frontmatter.description: Learn how to use your own custom domain with ngrok.

children.title: How to Change a Cloud Endpoint Domain

frontmatter.title: How to Change a Cloud Endpoint Domain
frontmatter.description: How to use the ngrok API to change the URL of your Cloud Endpoint with zero downtime.

examples.name: Implement the 'Front Door' Pattern
examples.description: By using a Cloud Endpoint and internal Agent Endpoints together, you loosely couple your gateway and services for extra flexibility.

examples.name: Route to Endpoints by Geography
examples.description: Show users content based on their region, comply with regulations, or ensure traffic hits the nearest endpoint for the lowest latency.

examples.name: Accelerate and Secure Your Wordpress Installation
examples.description: Improve your existing Wordpress installation with automatic TLS certificates, CDN acceleration/DDoS protection, and options to protect your admin dashboard.

examples.name: Offload Analytics to a Secondary Service
examples.description: Capture observability data from your gateway and send it to a self-hosted analytics service securely and without instrumenting your code.

examples.name: Validate Requests Against an Internal Identity Service
examples.description: Enrich your upstream service with customer details, use other authentication methods, and simplify DX by adding identity logic to your gateway through an HTTP request.

examples.name: Apply Rate Limits (Pre-Tiering) Based on Identity or CRM Services
examples.description: Use existing customer data and your service's pricing model to apply the proper rate limit to a user's IP address.

examples.name: Lock Down Your Admin Dashboards
examples.description: Add multiple layers of protection and authentication to your dashboards to prevent threat actors from even attempting attacks.

examples.name: Deploy a Zero-Code Maintenance Mode for Your Services
examples.description: Deploy a consistent maintenance message for your services without having to spin up new services or make changes to your network.

examples.name: Authenticate and Route API vs. App Traffic Based on User Agent
examples.description: Automatically enforce the right type of AuthN and route requests to the appropriate upstream service from the same hostname and path.

examples.name: Create Secure Public Developer Environments
examples.description: Use a shared wildcard domain to control exposing services, route requests to the right local service, and apply centralized traffic policies like auth or IP restrictions.

examples.name: Route to Services Based on OIDC Authentication
examples.description: Use the data returned by your OIDC provider to route authenticated requsets to specific upstream services.

examples.name: Deploy Custom Error Pages
examples.description: Instead of a blank page or HTTP error code, ensure your services automatically failover to error pages with clear details and instructions.

examples.name: Expose and Secure Your Self-Hosted Ollama API
examples.description: Use ngrok to create a public endpoint for your local LLM, enabling remote access and integration, while also adding authentication and access control.

examples.name: Expose and Secure Your Self-Hosted n8n Workflows
examples.description: Get your n8n instance online to share with colleagues or receive webhook data with security measures desinged for production usage.

examples.name: Secure Your Public Minecraft Server
examples.description: Unwanted players can quickly destroy your hard work, but you can restrict access by letting in a specific set of IP addresses.

examples.name: Intercept and Rewrite Headers in HTTP Redirect Responses
examples.description: By routing to internal services and editing headers, you can manipulate traffic in ways that allow you to seamlessly access customer networks and upstream services despite their network topology.

examples.name: Combine Authentication Methods
examples.description: Support multiple ways for your users to connect to upstream services with a flexible OR operator pattern.

categories.name: Connection Modification
categories.description: Actions that can modify incoming connections.

categories.name: Request Modification
categories.description: Actions that can modify incoming requests.

categories.name: Response Modification
categories.description: Actions that can modify outgoing responses.

categories.name: Security & Validation
categories.description: Actions that enforce security rules or validate incoming requests.

categories.name: Traffic Control
categories.description: Actions that directly control traffic flow by denying, forwarding, or restricting access.

actions.name: Add Headers
actions.description: Add headers to your incoming requests or outgoing responses.

actions.name: Basic Auth
actions.description: Enforce HTTP Basic Auth for your HTTP endpoints.

actions.name: Circuit Breaker
actions.description: Maintain system reliability by rejecting requests when error rates exceed defined thresholds.

actions.name: Compress Response
actions.description: Compress HTTP response bodies from your upstream server.

actions.name: Custom Response
actions.description: Send a custom HTTP response directly back to the client.

actions.name: Deny
actions.description: Deny incoming traffic to your endpoint at the HTTP layer.

actions.name: Forward Internal
actions.description: Forward traffic to an internal endpoint within the same ngrok account.

actions.name: HTTP Request
actions.description: Send an HTTP request to a third-party API and return the response.

actions.name: JWT Validation
actions.description: Validate JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) on your incoming requests.

actions.name: Log
actions.description: Add log metadata to events for logging and monitoring.

actions.name: OAuth
actions.description: Add OAuth login for your HTTP endpoints.

actions.name: OpenID Connect (OIDC)
actions.description: Add OpenID Connect login for your HTTP endpoints.

actions.name: OWASP/CRS Request
actions.description: Add OWASP CoreRuleSet to incoming HTTP requests to your endpoints.

actions.name: OWASP/CRS Response
actions.description: Add OWASP CoreRuleSet to outgoing HTTP responses from your endpoints.

actions.name: Rate Limit
actions.description: Rate limit incoming traffic to your endpoint before it hits your upstream servers.

actions.name: Redirect
actions.description: Redirect users through URL transformations using regular expressions.

actions.name: Remove Headers
actions.description: Remove headers from incoming requests or outgoing responses.

actions.name: Restrict IPs
actions.description: Allow or deny incoming traffic based on the client IP.

actions.name: Set Vars
actions.description: Set custom variables for use in your traffic policy.

actions.name: Terminate TLS
actions.description: Control the behavior of TLS termination on your endpoints.

actions.name: URL Rewrite
actions.description: Rewrite request URLs transparently using regular expressions.

actions.name: Verify Webhook
actions.description: Validate incoming signatures against a known secret to ensure authenticity.

Quickstart: Kubernetes Ingress
frontmatter.description: Set up an ngrok Ingress Controller to expose Kubernetes services using standard Ingress resources for simple, drop-in HTTP routing.

frontmatter.title: Quickstart: Kubernetes Gateway API
frontmatter.description: Use ngrok with the Kubernetes Gateway API for advanced routing, policy control, and future-proof ingress configuration.

frontmatter.title: Quickstart: Kubernetes Custom Resources
frontmatter.description: Leverage ngrok’s custom Kubernetes CRDs for the simplest path, with the least amount of YAML, to exposing your Kubernetes services to the public internet.

frontmatter.title: Quickstart: Kubernetes Endpoints
frontmatter.description: Connect any API or app to your Kubernetes clusters for local service projection, cross-cluster communication, and much more.

frontmatter.title: Load Balancing Between Multiple Kubernetes Clusters
frontmatter.description: Use Endpoint Pooling to split traffic between any number of clusters without needing to deploy external services.

frontmatter.name: argocd
frontmatter.title: Argo CD
frontmatter.description: Argo CD is the leading declarative GitOps continuous delivery tool for Kubernetes. With Argo CD, you store all your applications, configurations, and environments in one or more Git repositories so that your deployment and lifecycle management processes are automated, auditable, and repeatable.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress to apps and APIs running on Kubernetes clusters with GitOps/APIOps deployments.

frontmatter.name: amazon-eks
frontmatter.title: Amazon EKS
frontmatter.description: Use the ngrok Kubernetes Operator on Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) to provide instant ingress to your production services
frontmatter.excerpt: ngrok Kubernetes Operator on Amazon EKS

frontmatter.name: microsoft-entra-id
frontmatter.title: Microsoft Entra ID
frontmatter.description:
Secure access to ngrok tunnels with Microsoft Entra ID. 
No VPNs, Firewalls, or complex network rules required.
frontmatter.excerpt: Secure access to ngrok tunnels with Microsoft Entra ID.

frontmatter.name: azure-aks
frontmatter.title: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)
frontmatter.description: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) is managed Kubernetes environment from Microsoft. AKS simplifies the deployment, health monitoring, and maintenance of cloud native applications, whether you deploy them in Azure, in on-premises data centers, or at the edge.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to apps running on Kubernetes clusters managed by Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS).

frontmatter.name: consul
frontmatter.title: Hashicorp Consul
frontmatter.description: HashiCorp Consul is a service networking solution that enables teams to manage secure network connectivity between services and across on-prem and multi-cloud environments and runtimes. ngrok compliments Consul nicely by providing a cloud agnostic Ingress as a Service to allow traffic to reach services running in your Consul Service Mesh.
frontmatter.excerpt: Easily allow Ingress traffic to services running in your Consul Service Mesh

frontmatter.name: digitalocean
frontmatter.title: DigitalOcean
frontmatter.description: DigitalOcean is a cloud service provider focused on developers, startups, and small-to-midsize businesess. ngrok and DigitialOcean compliment one another by providing a developer-friendly way to deploy and manage complex Kubernetes apps in multiple regions around the globe with less friction and cognitive load.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to apps running on clusters managed by DigitalOcean.

frontmatter.name: google-gke
frontmatter.title: Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE)
frontmatter.description: Use the ngrok Kubernetes Operator on Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) to provide instant ingress to your production services
frontmatter.excerpt: Run the ngrok Kubernetes Operator on Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE).

frontmatter.name: linkerd
frontmatter.title: Linkerd
frontmatter.description: Linkerd is an open source service mesh designed to simplify and secure microservices communicatation within Kubernetes clusters. ngrok and Linkerd integrate well together to abstract away complexity around encrypted traffic ingress while also adding more observable networking data and resiliency.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to any Kubernetes app running on top of a Linkerd service mesh.

frontmatter.name: MicroK8s
frontmatter.title: Canonical MicroK8s
frontmatter.description: Canonical MicroK8s is an open-source system for low-ops, minimal, production-ready Kubernetes. MicroK8s' single-node configuration, small size, and customizeable footprint lets you use it for local development, in minimal environments like GitHub's CI/CD, or using Kubernetes on IoT hardware.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to apps running on Kubernetes clusters managed by Canonical MicroK8s.

frontmatter.name: rancher
frontmatter.title: Rancher
frontmatter.description: Rancher is an open source container management platform built for organizations adopting containers and deploying them in production Kubernetes environments. Together, ngrok and Rancher help DevOps teams manage and observe multiple clusters while creating a simpler developer experience around add traffic ingress to their microservices applications.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to applications operating in a Rancher-based management platform.

frontmatter.name: rafay
frontmatter.title: Rafay
frontmatter.description: Rafay is a SaaS-based cloud controller that helps platform and DevOps teams manage their Kubernetes clusters and cloud environments. ngrok and Rafay compliment one another by simplifying developer self-service for creating standardized Kubernetes clusters and configurations for their apps.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to applications running on Rafay's Kubernetes management platform.

frontmatter.name: spectro-cloud
frontmatter.title: Spectro Cloud
frontmatter.description: Palette, from Spectro Cloud, is a profile-based Kubernetes management platform for managing the lifecycle of multiple environments in data centers or the cloud.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to applications operating in a cluster managed by the Palette platform.

frontmatter.name: vcluster
frontmatter.title: vcluster
frontmatter.description: vcluster is an open source project for creating virtual clusters that run inside regular namespaces, which provides strong isolation and easy access for multiple tenants with low cost and overhead. ngrok and vcluster compliment one another to simplify how developers add and control traffic ingress to applications running in a virtual cluster.
frontmatter.excerpt: Quickly add ingress traffic to applications running in virtual clusters.
